div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,239] ALEXANDRIA, THURSDAY, AUGUST 3, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

THURSDAY, AUGUST 3, 1905.
RUSSIA'S PRESTIGE IN THE NEAR EAST.

Probably owing to the fact that the Japa- nese have burst the bubble of Russian invin- cibility, even the Tsar's only friend does not treat his angust patron with the humility of former years. Mr. Solovief, the Charge d’Af- faires in Montenegro, has been suddenly recalled as the result of a quarrel which he has just had with the Crown Prince Danilo, who does not appear to be as devoted to Russia as his father has always been. The Prince had arranged for a grand official opening of the new buildings of the Italo- Montenegrin Tobacco Monopoly at Podgo- rica, to which everyone was bidden. The day before the fete came the news of the annihilation of the Russian fleet in the battle of the Sea of Japan. In the absence of the Russian Minister, Mr. Solovief telegraphed to the Prince and asked him to put off the festivities, or at any rate to take care that the two battalions of Montenegrin troops at Pod- gorica, who are paid by the Tsar, did not take part. The Prince replied that the fete was a national one, and that regrettable as the Rus- sian disaster was, it could make no difference, as Montenegro was an absolutely independent State. The ceremony took place ; and, what was worse, at the banquet in the evening Prince Danilo made a speech in which he

div.head: Sunlight
div.p: There is no rubbing and scrubbing with
Sunlight Soap
One bar of it, when used according to directions, will do more than two bars of common soap.
Soap

praised the valour of the Japanese and the genius of Admiral Togo. The result was that Mr. Solovief fell a victim to his zeal, for the Russian Minister no longer carries matters with a high hand in Cettigne.

Whether the sense of gratitude for the aid rendered to Bulgaria in 1877 has survived the remarkable performances of Russian diplomacy at Sofia between 1884-1890, or not, will probably stand by her erstwhile protector from interested motives. Roumania and Turkey are possible foes of the Bulgar and, however admirable the Bulgarian army, he certainty of an attack in the rear and the grave doubt whether Russia could give, my effective aid, during a campaign carried on for the liberation of Macedonia, is cal- culated to impress the advantages of a pacific policy upon the Bulgarian people. In Asia Minor there are rumours of ominous movements of Turkish troops on the frontier of the Transcaucasian Province, when from all accounts something like a civil war is raging between Moslem and Armenian, while the garrisons fire impartially at both factions, but it is hard to believe that the Ottoman Government would venture to attack a great land Power, especially in days when Arabia is ablaze and Syria arming. But Russian prestige has suffered throughout the Turkish dominions, while German prestige has gained correspondingly, and the repre sentations that the Tsar’s Government may make on behalf of the Eastern Christians during the next few years are not likely to receive the same nervous attention that was formerly given. The decline of the prestige of Russia must encourage the ardent parti- sans of the Pan-Islamic movement and the ingenious promoters of a "Deutsch Islamitisch” combination in the Near East. It is not sat- irising that even the most liberally minded Eastern Christians showed a tendency to regard the battle of Tsusima and the over- throw of the Russian armies at Mukden as very doubtful blessings.

div.head: RUSSIAN REFORMERS.
div.p: The “Standard” has published from its correspondent at Moscow the address adopted by the Zemstvoists last week, which has been likened to the English Grand Re- monstrance. It is a document of the highest historic importance, and constitutes a ter- rible indictment of the Bureaucracy. The manifesto is said to have been drawn up by 172 delegates to the Zemstvos, and 112 repre- sentatives of the municipalities, and as a statement of the views of the constitutional reference will excite great attention abroad as well as at home, though, except through the medium of the foreign papers, it is hardly accessible to home readers. The English trans- lation occupies nearly four columns, but its gist may be compressed into a few words. Its authors point out how responsibility has been evaded by the authorities. The people are still in darkness as to the massacre of Jan- uary 22, “which will take its place in history alongside the night of St. Bartholo- mew.” Nobody knows who gave the illegal order to fire upon the defenceless demonstra- tors. The promised investigation has not been made, and it is even permissible to believe that the authors of the crime have been rewarded. One of the conclusions is that it is impossible to believe in the earnest- ness of the Government in carrying out re- forms, for which, says the manifesto, “we can wait no more.” In view of the action of the reformers it is not surprising to read in the “Times” that even military circles are much more concerned with politics than with strategy, and that officers are in favor of a Constitution. The “Russ” is cited as authority for the statement that Russians now scarcely look at the war telegrams. The campaign against Bureaucratic tyranny and repression seems to monopolise their attention.

div.head: RUSSIA AND PEACE.
DIFFICULTIES IN THE WAY.
div.p: GOVERNMENT STANDPOINT
St. Petersburg, August 2.

The conviction is growing here that peace cannot be concluded by the present Russian Government because it does not feel sufficiently supported by the nation to agree to the cession of territory or the payment of an indemnity, while it is realised that Japan cannot terminate the struggle without one or the other, or both. It is further recognised that Saghalien is lost for ever, thus placing the whole of the Amur under Japanese influence, but the present Go- vernment refuses' to admit the logic of events. (Reuter.)

div.head: M. WITTE IN NEW YORK.
ALLEGED INTERVIEW.
div.p: New York, August 2.

M. Witte has arrived here. He has been interviewed by the “New York Herald.” He said he is afraid that the negotiations will end within a week, as the Japanese conditions are to be so intolerable that they do not admit of discussion.
(Later) M. Witte repudiates the statements attributed to him by the “Herald.” (Reuter.) Vancouver (B.C.), August 2 M. Sokotilof, one of the Russian plenipoten- tiaries, has arrived here. (Reuter.)

div.head: FRANCE AND GERMANY.
MOROCCO CONFERENCE PROGRAMME.
div.p: Paths, August 2.

M. Rouvier has communicated to Prince Ra- dolin the text of France’s proposals regarding the programme of the Morocco conference. Two reforms are particularly indicated therein; they concern the security of persons and the financial question. (Havas.)

div.head: MISSISSIPPI AND LOUISIANA.
A PATROL INCIDENT.
div.p: New Orleans, August 2.

Owing to the yellow fever the patrols of the State of Mississippi have seized eighteen Louisiana fishing-boats, in connection with the quarantine. The Louisiana authorities have sent a strong protest to Washington, and in the meanwhile they are equipping a steamer aimed with howitzers and troops to prevent any further aggression on the part of Mississip- pians. (Reuter.)

div.head: FOOD SUPPLIES IN WAR.
COMMISSION’S REPORT.
div.p: London, August 2.

The Commission on Food Supplies in Time of War has completed its report, which is re- assuring, as no enemy would be able to block- ade the entire British coast, and nothing could prevent ample importation of all necessary supplies. A minority headed by the Duke of Sutherland takes an alarmist view, and urges a national system of grain storage. (Reuter.)

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL.
div.p: Stray and Ownerless Dogs found in the Abdeen quarter of Cairo during the night of Friday and at daybreak on Saturday will be poisoned by the police.
A Telephone Wire Thief.—An Arab was arrested yesterday near Babour el Moya- street while cutting the telephone wire of the Daira Khassa. He admitted that this was not his first theft.

A Drunkard’s End — The Cairo police found a native in an advanced state of intoxi- cation lying in the Abou el Ela-boulevard and removed him to the Boulac caracol, where he expired shortly afterwards.

The Plague.—Yesterday’s bulletin records a fresh case at Alexandria, the patient being a coffee-house keeper. A other case occurred in the same coffee-house, which is situated at Kom el Nadoura, on the 29th ulto.

Delta Barrage.—The Irrigation Depart- ment professes ignorance as to when the Delta Barrage will be opened. It is not improbable that the barrage may not be opened at all this year if the Nile Hood remains as low as it is now.

Suez Canal.—6 vessels passed through the Canal on the 31st July, 3 of which were British, 1 German, 1 French, 1 Argentine. The receipts for the day were frs. 175,237.95, making the total receipts for the month of July frs. 9.031,960.10, the number of vessels being 326.

San Stefano Casino —We may remind our readers that the fourth vocal and instrumental concert takes place at the casino this afternoon. The vocal part, of which we published the pro- gramme yesterday, will commence: at 6.30 p.m. On Saturday evening, beginning at half- past nine, there will be a night fete, when the attractions include Venetian illuminations, fireworks, and a grand concert.

Daira Sanieh Mosques. — The Finance Ministry is said to be studying with the Wakfs Administration the question as to who will bear the cost of upkeep of the mosques at present taken care of by the Daira Sanieh. It is very probable that the Wakfs Administra- tion will take charge of these mosques, defray the expenses connected therewith, and see to their management.

La Revue Internationale d’Egypte.—The fourth number of this review, which has just appeared,contains some very interesting matter, an article on Egypt and its conquerors by “Y.” and another by M. L Fieri, entitled “The India of To-day,” being well worth reading.The story of Richard Wagner’s relations with Matilda Wesendonck is concluded, while M. Delines, in “Lettres Allemandes,” shows an amazing inability to grasp the real meaning of Friedrich Nietzsche’s teaching. It is a pity he has not studied Emile Fagnet’s appreciation of the last philosopher. M. R. Ganivet’s notes on the Separation of the Church and State’ and on the “Animal Mummies of Ancient Egypt” are, unhappily for the reader, too brief, but his critique of M. Albert Gayet’s “Coins d’Egypte ignores” does full justice to the dramatic imagination of the writer.

Swiss National Fete.—On Tuesday a ban- quet was given by the Swiss colony of Alex- andria at the Beau-Rivage Hotel, Ramleh, on the occasion of the ninety-first anniversary of the declaration of Swiss independence. Quite 100 members of the colony were present at a most enjoyable function; among them many ladies, and all the proceedings were marked by the utmost cordiality and good humour. The speeches were brief (Republican simplicity extends even to after-dinner oratory in Swit- zerland) but made up in humour and patriotism for what they lacked in length. M. Jacot and Mr. Karcher’s speeches were loudly applauded, and M. Stutz proposed the health of the ladies with grace and wit Patriotic songs, Volkslieder, and short comic sketches helped to amuse the company and to recall memories of Switzerland, and it was not till after mid- night that the toast of the Swiss Confederation was honored and the company broke up—till next year.

A Little Knowledge, &c.—We cull the following from the All Saints’ Church Maga- zine:- It was Mark Twain who said that he could always speak best upon subjects of which he knew nothing, because he was then entirely unhampered by facts. Of the fact that he is not the only person thus gifted there can be little doubt. In Egypt the subject which seems to illustrate most freely and frequently this propensity in men is that of the Copts. Who are the Copts ? and at once people who are entirely unhampered by fact will seize this opportunity for a display of originality. Recently in Cairo conversation turning upon foreign missions a man expressed himself as follows : "A great many foreign missions are failures, but none so great as the attempt to Christianise the Copts.” Needless to say he meant by Copts the Mohamedans in Egypt. But what can surpass the following remarkable statement as to who the Copts are, one made quite recently in Cairo. A. “The Copts; who are the Copts ?” B. “O, don’t you know who the Copts are; they are a sect of the Mohamedans, a sort of Buddhist you know!”

div.head: GERMANY AND EGYPT.
div.p: THE TEUTON’S PROGRESS.

The “Globe’s” Cairo correspondent writes:— The most sanguine would find it difficult to discover any cause for self-gratulation in the figures of British trade with Egypt during May, published by the Egyptian Customs Administration. Of late the German Press has been conspicuous in glorifying itself upon the expansion of German commerce in Egypt, and no one can deny that there is abundant cause for reasonable elation among the pan- Germanist party, who may at any time seek to transfer to the Nile the tactics that were played within Morocco. German coal is rapidly assuming a foremost place among her ex- ports to Egypt; that is stroke number one against England. A Norddeutscher pas- senger service has been instituted between Marseilles and Alexandria ; that is stroke number two against, France, which for years has enjoyed almost a prescriptive right to the monopoly of Marseilles-Alexandria shipping. In May British exports to Egypt declined in practically every department—or in those rare cases where an increase was recorded, such as in iron, which showed an advance of £6,392, a fall of £9,286 occurred in machinery. The sum of these individual instances is that in the month of increased import trade that May was, namely, a total of £1,533,600 representing an addition of£81,730 over 1904, Great Britain alone out of European countries suffered a de- cline, in spite of unusual activity in flour, cotton fabrics, timber, and other leading imports from the Continent. Germany, on the other hand, secured a larger share of Egyptian cus- tom than ever. It is not surprising that in face of these results, Germany should be casting her eyes on the Sudan, so soon as the new railway between the Red Sea and the Nile shall be completed. Such appear to be her intentions as described for us in general terms by one of the commercial journals of Berlin. At the entrance to Egypt, in Alexandria and Port Said; in the capital, Cairo ; at the entrance to the Sudan, namely, in Suakin and Port-Sudan, and in the near future along the Nile itself by the flotilla to be inaugurated by the Hamburg- America Company, Germany has contrived to establish herself unassailably throughout Anglo-Egyptian territory.
EGYPT, GREECE, AND ITALY.

The negotiations with Greece and Italy for the conclusion of a commercial convention with Egypt will be resumed next winter, on the return of the Diplomatic Agents of the Powers, who will have been able, during their absence in Europe, to take the advice of their respective governments on the subject. Nego- tiations with the same object will be opened with Austria.
THE ETHIOPIAN RAILWAY

The "Depeche Coloniale” publishes the text of a letter addressed to the French Colonial Minister by the Compagnie Imperiale des Chemins de Fer Ethiopiens, protesting against a statement in the report presented to the general meeting of the New African Company last week. In this report the board of directors speak of the success of their efforts in promot- ing the internationalisation of that railway. The French company declare that it is impos- sible that the French Government should agree to the internationalisation of a line for which France makes such a considerable sacrifice under the law of April 6, 1902. They are sure that the directors of the New African Com- pany have been misinformed, or, rather, have misinterpreted the news respecting the course of the negotiations which they have published at different times. They have erroneously con- cluded that the admission of a certain number of foreign directors on the board of the railway company signified its complete internationalisa- tion—an interpretation against which the com- pany protest as not being in agreement with the facts, with their own wishes, or with the desires of any of the Governments interested in the present negotiations.
MURDER IN THE ATTARIN.

A shocking murder was committed at about 1.45 p.m. yesterday in Attarin-street. It ap- pears that an Italian named Riccardo Calen- drini had for some days made a butt of a com- patriot, one Nicodemo Abbruzzese, and had frequently passed from jests to insults. While Abbruzzese was passing Calandrini’s door yesterday in the company of a woman, the latter called to him “robba vecchia,” Abbruzzese returned and asked if the expression was applied to him. Calandrini replied that it was. A quarrel followed, blows followed words, and Abbruzzese suddenly drew a knife and stabbed his persecutor twice in the chest. The injured man took two or three steps towards the Attarin Pharmacy and collapsed into the arms of a passer by who had rushed to his aid. In a few seconds he was dead. The murderer took to flight but went shortly after the occurrence to the Italian Consulate, where he gave himself up and con- fessed his crime.
STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
The Messageries Maritimes S.S. Portugal arrived at Marseilles from Alexandria yester- day at 5 a m.
The Papayanni S.S. Falernian left Malta yesterday afternoon and is expected here on Sunday morning.
The Ellerman S.S. Flavian sailed from Liver- pool for Alexandria direct on Wednesday.

div.head: NOTES FROM SUAKIN.
div.p: SUAKIN-ATBARA RAILWAY.
( From our Correspondent. )
Suakin, July 26.

The railway line will be joined at both Railheads on the 12th September, 1905, but nothing has been said as to an inaugural ceremony on that day. There is a rumour that a month’s salary will be given to all who took part in the building of this railway as a grati- fication to those who have served a year or over, as soon as both ends are joined. The official opening of the Suakin-Atbara line may probably take place later on. The new line from Sallom to Port Sudan will commence in the latter end of September, and will be com- pleted about the beginning of November.
ARRIVAL OF RAILWAY MATERIAL

The British steamer Antonio arrived from England on the 22nd inst. with a very large consignment of material, such as steel rails and sleepers, steel bridges, and stores, for the Suakin-Atbara Railways.
DEPARTURES.

The Khedivial Mail steamer Fayoum leaves to-day for Suez. Among her passengers are : Dr. Fornisto, director of the quarantine station here, who is now transferred to another station, and Mr. Michele Capato, of the well-known firm of Messrs. Cepato, who is going to spend the summer in Alexandria.
GREEK MARRIAGE

A Greek marriage took place at Graham’s Point for the first on Friday, 21st inst. between Mr. Chrisostomo Pentzopoulo, of the Suakin-Atbara line, and Miss Mary Lorando. The Greek-Orthodox priest, Father Constantino Garofalo, who performed the ceremony, came from Asmara (Erythrea) for the occasion, and the marriage took place at the bridegroom’s residence, in one of the railway cottages at Graham’s Point. The bride was given away by her brother, Mr. Gerasimo Lorando, assist- ant workshop foreman, Suakin Railways. The guests were numerous and several Euro- pean families came over by boat from Suakin. Amongst the principal guests were: Mr. Smail, loco. and stores superintendent, Mr. Hewson, assistant loco. superintendent, Mr. Mishallany, district traffic manager, Mr. Gaiger, English se- cretary, Mr. Warne, chief engineer, Suakin rail- way condensors, Mr. Bailey, inspector of bridges, Mr. Campbell, assistant loco. foreman, and several others belonging to the Suakin Rail- ways, also a great number of Europeans from Suakin town, amongst whom were some of the principal merchants, Mr Moss, assistant com- mandant of police, Dr. Tornista, director of the quarantine camp, etc. A number of Egypt- ian officers were also present. Alter the mar- riage ceremony festivities were held at the married couple’s residence, and were kept up with the greatest enthusiasm until a late hour.
SPORTS.

The Suakin Sporting Club held their second pigeon shoot on Friday, 21st inst. There was a very large attendance, and an enjoyable afternoon was spent. Mr. Gaiger was successful in obtaining the first prize in the two most important events of the day. Other good shots were Messrs. Archer, Moss, Hodges, and Dello Strologo.

div.head: AN EGYPTIAN MINING CONCESSION
div.p: Last week, in the Chancery Division, London, before Mr. Justice Kekewich, Mr. a Beckett Terrell said he had to apply in the case of Brown v. Haig for an injunction to restrain the defendant from dealing in certain con- cessions and licences for mining minerals in the Sudan. The case arose out of an agree- ment between the plaintiff and the defendant Haig, made in 1901. The notion was originally commenced by Brown for an account of deal- ings in the concession. Right to the account was denied by the defendant, and the notion was brought on for trial before Mr. Justice Joyce, and an order was made. The suggestion was made that the plaintiff was not a partner with the defendant. It was suggested that the plaintiff claimed profits, but did not admit his liability as a partner. In the action before Mr. Justice Joyce the plaintiff admitted that he was bound to contribute one equal third of the expenditure in connection with the concession, and the Court ordered the matter to be referred to the Official Referee to take an ac- count. The reference was now proceeding. Plaintiff applied to Haig for particulars as to existing concessions, and then came a request from Haig for the whole of the rent of the concession, and defendant said that unless he got that he would sell the concessions for what he could get, but offering at the same time to consider any offer by plaintiff for a lease. Counsel said that plaintiff was now in a position to make a very substantial offer for the concessions if they were offered by tender. He asked his Lordship to say that Haig should not be allowed to sell, as he proposed, and that there should be a direction of the Court that the property should be offered for sale by tender or otherwise.

Mr. Terrell said that the difficulty was as to the legal estate- if there was such a thing in a Sudan concession. The concessions stood in the name of the defendant, who was unwilling to pay the rents, and surely he was entitled to step in and save the property.
His Lordship laid that be thought the judg- ment was conclusive against the motion, and that it should be dismissed, with costs.

div.head: NOTES FROM PORT SAID
div.p: CHILIAN TRAINING SHIP.
(From our Correspondent).
Port Said, Wednesday.

On Monday, the Chilian training-ship “Pre- sidente Sarmiente” arrived here, and now offers to the public of Port Said a Sight such as they are not likely to see again; She is one of the old-time corvettes, with yards on all masts and fitted with auxiliary steam power; Her crew numbers 301, of whom a large number are cadets and apprentices. The vessel is to leave here early next week.
SUEZ CANAL COMPANY.

M. Doyen, the “sous agent superieur” of the Canal Company, arrived by. the P. & 0. Himalaya, which reached here yesterday after- noon and entered the Canal at 10 a.m. to- day. He is relieving the Comte de Serionne, who is, I hear, shortly going on leave. M. Doyen was accompanied by M. Lavalette, the director of the Domaine commune.
NEW MAIL STEAMERS.

I hear to-day of a new company which is now building three vessels to undertake the service of mails between here and Cyprus in connection with the Isis and Osiris. The company is of recent formation and from all accounts should have a successful future.
ANOTHER COLLIER ON FIRE.

Yet another fire has occurred in one of the Baltic Fleet colliers. The S.S. Woglinde, it appears, discovered fire in her after-holds last night while near kil. 54 in the Canal, and telegraphed up for pomps and fire ap- paratus to be ready for her on arrival here. She has just reached Port Said, and on going on board I was informed that numbers of cases of a like nature had occurred among these colliers. It becomes a somewhat serious matter, this procession of ships with fire in their holds. The Woglinde is to be flooded, I hear, as was the Macedonia, which latter is still discharging, though one is inclined to ask the reason why, as she would be doing at least equally well were she to proceed to her destination (Sebastopol) and put all her coal out there.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Mahmoud Pasha Sidky, Governor of Alex- andria, leaves Trieste for Egypt on the 21st inst.
Mouheb Bey, Moudir of Sharkieh, is expect- ed to leave for Europe on the 21st inst.
The Legislative Council, at its meeting on Tuesday, decided to send a letter of condo- lence in the name of the Council to the mem- bers of the late Grand Mufti’s family.
Mr. Webb arrives at Cairo to-morrow from Assouan.
H. I. M. the German Emperor has conferred the Grand Cross of the Crown of Prussia on Dr. Duca Pasha, ex-Ottoman delegate on the Quarantine Board.
A requiem mass for the repose of the soul of the late Zareh S. Sevasly Bey will be held on Sunday next at 10.30 a.m. at the Church of SS. Peter and Paul.

Among the latest arrivals at the Savoy Hotel, Port Said, we notice Mr. P.W. Browne, Major Hardy, R.A.M.C., Mrs. Hardy and child, M. Daniel Sercke, M. van den Bergh, Mr. Mac- Closkey, Mr. F.P. Doherty, Mr. Jennings, Mr. H. V. Fletcher, Dr. Elliot-Smith, Mr. Hallam, Mrs. E.M. Fox, Master Fox, Mr. A. Lucas, Col. Rawnsley, D.S.O.

div.head: EGYPTIAN SHARE MARKET.
div.p: (From our financial correspondent).
London, July 28.

Owing to the holiday season coming on, and to the want of any new developments in the Far and Near East, markets remain quite featureless, and offer no new point of interest. A good general tone exists, due to the large amount of support accorded to foreign bonds by the Continent, especially Germany, who is said to have been making large purchases of Japanese bonds through the banking houses in Berlin.

Several Continental correspondents, anxious to give a reasonfor the meeting of the Tsar and the Kaiser, have circulated a report that the Kaiser advised the Tsar to continue the war until the Russian forces obtained a victory, but the suggestion meets with no serious credence in Stock Exchange circles. It is the belief there that no change has been made in the instructions given to M. Witte by the Emperor Nicholas at Peterhof.

By the time the holidays are out of the way we ought to see a strong revival in stock markets, if for no other reasons than those ex- plained in a leading article which appeared in the London “Times” of the 26th inst. It was there pointed out that the steady increase in the production of gold not only in South Africa, but the world over is gradually begin- ning to make itself felt—just at present in the low price of money, which eventually, in the near future, must mean a depreciation in the value of gold, and consequently a rise in prices all round. This is an axiom, and consequently those traders who have watched the growing of gold are confidently looking for an increased trade with higher prices ruling for some time, which means prosperity all round.

In the market-for Home Government secur- ities, Consols showed a bettor tendency, and were at one time as good as 90 6/16, but left off at 90 1/4 btoh for money and the August account, showing a rise of 11/16 on balance. Japanese bonds rose from 1/4 to 1/2, the new issue closing at 2 premium. Russians are steady, It is re- ported from St. Petersburg that Berlin bankers are acquiring 6 per cent. Exchequer bonds At 2 per cent., and it is pointed out as significant that depositors in St. Petersburg banks have invested 50,000,000 roubles in foreign se- curities during recent weeks.

In the mining section, South Africans are very dull, Westralians being the only market showing any activity. Egyptian stocks are steady, the firmest point being Bank shares, which hold their prices well. National Bank new shares showed an advance of 1/8 to 7 1/4 premium. Daira Sanieh rose 1/4 to 28 3/8, the Deferred 2 to 182. Mines are quite idle^ and although there has been a little more enquiry for Egyptian mines lately, and some buying of Nile Valleys and United African to lock up, there is little or no change in prices.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY.
KHEDIVIAL YACHT CLUB.
div.p: REGATTA
The following is the result of yesterday's races for the Sporting Club's cups :-
Class I
Class II

There was a moderate breeze from the N.W., and the finishes in both classes were very good. The Jenny was leading well in Class I., when her mast carried away and she had to give up. Although the Celtic crossed the line first she was disqualified by the committee on a foul that she had with the Leman at the break- water elbow buoy ; the Leman therefore won the cup. There were not many staarters in Class II. The Laurea had several mishaps, such as carrying away her spinnaker boom in starting and her cross-trees when outside.
BRITISH RIFLE CLUB (ALEX).
There will be no practice on Saturday next, 5th inst.

div.head: QUESTIONS MUNICIPALES
Le Parc Quarantenaire de Chatby
div.p: Eu dépit des protestations de la Municipa lité, le Ministre de l’Intérieur vient de décider que le débarquement des bovidés provenant do pays infectés aura lieu à Cbatby, parce que cette localité a “toujours servi de parc qua- rantenaire et que le Gouvernement n'a pas d’autre emplacement disponible pour servir au débarquement du bétail en qnestion.’’ A ce'a la Municipalité ne trouve rien à répondre et se borne à émettre le vœu que l’affectation do Chatby au débarquement ne soit que provisoire.

C’est pour elle le fruit de mille efforts perdu. 11 ne lui aura donc rien servi de débarrasser Cbatby de tous les établissements insalubres, abattoir, parc quarantanaire, lazaret, tanneries, pour les transporter au Mex et ruiner cette localité. Les espérances d’habiles spéculateurs fondées sur une plus-value énorme des terrains se trouvera du même coup anéantie. Et voilà ces excellents propriétaires et conseillers muets, consternés par un événement qu’ils n’ont pas prévu.

Cependant le débarquement n’aura pas lien et nous sommes étonnés de voir que dans un collège d’hommes aussi pratiques etseusés que le sont nos édiles il ne se soit pas trouvé un membre pour en montrer l’impossibilité. Le débarquement de bestiaux à Chatby est ma- tériellement impossible. A ce mot les intéressés respirent !

En effet, les bestiaux venant des localités contaminées, telles que la Russie et la Macé- doine, devront être, une fois arrivés dans le port, ou transportés par eau ou conduits par terre à Chatby. Par terre, le trajet ne peut avoir lieu, puisqu’il s’agit d’animaux suspects ou malades et qu’il y a danger de contamina- tion. Par eau le débarquement ne peut s’ef- fectuer, attendu que les navires ne peuvent pas accoster au Port-Est ni au-delà de Silsileh. Il ne peut être question de transport en ballon !

Ces constatations d’une évidence stupéfiante ont échappé à nos édiles ainsi qu’au Gouverne- ment. Sans doute Chatby a servi dans le temps de parc à bestiaux, parce qu’il y avait aussi l’abattoir, mais il s’agissait d’animaux venant de l’intérieur du pays et non de localités infectées. Le parc quarantenairo se trouvait près de la douane. Il est vrai qu’à cause de son insuffisance il fallait souvent transporter le surplus par terre au parc de Chatby ; mais qui ne voit le danger d’un pareil transport et l’inu- tilité des mesures prises, si la première d’entre elles, l'isolement, n’est pas observée. A cette époque d’ailleurs ce transport pouvait s’expli- quer par la présence de l’abattoir. Aujourd’hui ce motif n’existe plus.

Si le Gouvernement s’obstine à vouloir établir un parc qaarantenaire à Chatby, il doit donc nécessairement construire une jetée au Port- Est pour y permettre l’accostage des navires et le débarquement des marchandises. L’a- vantage qu’il procurera ainsi à notre ville com- pensera le domnmge qu’il lui aura causé par la création d’un parc quarantenairo en un point central et dans oe cas nous ne pourrons que l’en féliciter.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aukmrd1hui à midi et demie)
Le marché est plus faible sur les Banques et la Daïra, par suite des réalisations de fin du mois.
C’est ainsi que la Nationale fléchit de 27 5/3 à 27 17/32, l’Agricole de 14 3/16 à 14 1/8 et la Daïra de 28 7/16 à 28 5/16.
Par contre la Banque d’Athènes reprend de 127 3/4 a 128 acheteurs.
La Part de Fondateur Crédit Foncier gagne encore 200 francs et atteint 8,950 acheteurs.
En hausse également la Crown Brewery de 212 à 220, les Markets de 22,9 à 23, la Sait and Soda de 34/9 à 35/6 et la Nungovich de 10 à 10 3/16.
Le reste du marché demeure à peu près stationnaire, sans grandes transactions.

div.head: ON THE ISLAND OF IONA.
div.p: Considerable progress has been made with the restoration of Iona Cathedral, which, along with the other ancient architectural remains on the island, was conveyed, in 1899, by the late Duke of Argyll to trustees of the Church of Scotland. In the deed of gift his grace declared it to be his wish that the cathedral should be re-roofed and restored, so as to ad- mit of its being used for public worship. The choir is now available for divine service, and the opening service was recently held.

The celebrated ecclesiastical and other historic remains on the Island of Iona are, in several respects, unique, and the “illustrious island which,” in the familiar words of Dr. Johnson, “was once the luminary of the Caledonian regions” attracts numerous visitors and pious pilgrims from all parts of the world. The island itself has little natural beauty to charm the eye. To many, as to Montalbert, the aspects of nature upon and around Iona— the naked isles, the cloud-capped mountains, the restless ocean, the mists and rains and storms—are all mournful and oppressive. It is but a small speck—bleak, shaggy, and desolate in the wide expanse of the Atlantic. The real interest in Iona, that which every year brings thousands to its shores, lies in its sacred memories ; in the associations with the great missionary whose frail currach of wicker- work and hides grounded on its sands thirteen hundred years and more ago ; the man who, undeterred by hardship and danger, traversed the Hebrides, the Orkneys, and the Northern Highlands of Scotland, diffusing Christianity and civilisation, who here founded the monastic establishment which for centuries was a centre of learning and devotion, and who, on June 9, 597, passed away before the altar in the rude church his hands had helped to build.

When Columba was exiled from Ireland in 500, after the battle of Culdreimne, his kinsman, Conall, King of Dalriada, gave him that island of Hy which is now known as Iona, and which was situated on the confines of Pictish and Scotic jurisdiction. A community was formed with Columbia as abbot, and the evangelisation of the Northern Picts was begun. In the performance of their arduous, self-imposed labours Columba and the small company of disciples who had accompanied him from Ireland met with sur- prising success. Converts were made in ama- zingly large numbers ; hundreds of churches were established throughout the country, and Iona became not only a seat of learning and devotion, but a centre of political influence. And thus we find Columba, when a dispute arose as to the succession to the throne, virtually selecting a monarch for Dalriada— Aidan.

For many years after the death of the famous missionary Iona continued to maintain its influential position. But in the chronicle of the affairs of the island given in the Irish annals we find under date 794 the entry :— “Vastatio omnium insularum a gentilibus.” It was the first of many disastrous events in the history of Iona. Again and again during the ninth and tenth centuries the monastery was plundered by the Norsemen and its monks put to the sword. Still the island maintained its character as a “holy place.” It was long the burial-place of Scottish kings, and even, it is said, of other monarchs, including some from Ireland and from Norway. In the twelfth century a community of Benedictines was founded, and latterly the abbey became a dependency of that of Paisley. Amid all its vicissitudes, however, Iona continued to be held in peculiar esteem and reverence.

Every trace of Columba and his immediate successors having been swept away by the Norsemen, the ecclesiastical ruins now stand- ing, although they belong to an early period, are of much later date than those wattle huts which sheltered the saint and his fellow- pioneers. The oldest of the ruins are those of St. Odhrain’s Chapel, supposed to have been erected in the eleventh century by Margaret, the devout Queen of Malcolm Canmore, on the site of the humble church in which Columba himself worshipped. It is a small, oblong building, of red granite, with two very small lancet windows, and few traces of ornament. Nothing remains of this chapel but the bare walls. Adjoining, is the ancient burial-place known as the Reilig Odhrain, where lie, accord- ing to tradition, forty-eight Kings of Scotland, four Kings of Ireland, eight Kings of Norway, and a King of France. Most of these art nameless, and there is a good deal of scepticism now regarding the very large number of Roya personages supposed to be buried in Iona although it is beyond question that a goodly number of monarchs and chiefs lie in the Reilig Odhrain. The tombstones are very interesting. Some are six hundred years old and others are believed to be still more ancient.

In 1390 Donald of the Isles entrusted the beeping of Iona to Maclean of Duart, and after the Reformation it and the ecclesiastics and other buildings on it became the property of the family of Argyll. In common with other ecclesiastical buildings in Scotland those o Iona suffered a good deal at the time of and subsequent to the Reformation. But they suffered as much from neglect as from actual violence. The late Duke of Argyll, however, took a deep interest in the remains, and for nearly half a century preserved them carefully. It was, avowedly, with a view to secure the permanent protection of buildings of "such great historic interest to the whole Christian world” that be transfered them to a public trust in connection with the Church cf Scotland some time before his death.

div.head: THE WAR
THE ISLAND OF SAGHALIEN.
div.p: On the 18th of June an Osaka vernacular journal was able to publish in Japanese a complete map of the Island of Saghalien on the comparatively large scale of 40 miles to the inch, setting forth the name and situation of every fishing village along the coast, and, as far as practicable, every inhabited spot in the interior of the island. According to the Japanese geographers’ calculations the length is 670 miles from north to south, the width varying from 17 miles at the narrowest part to 105 miles at the broadest, the total area being only about one half that which it is usually computed to be. It actually amounts to 20,560 square miles, or about one-sixth of the area of the British Isles, and the popula- tion is 33,000, of whom 29,000 are of Russian origin. This leaves us with about 4,000 as the actual numbers of the Ainu or Ghilyak aborigines. The only practicable roads are two in number, one of which, starting from Korsa- kovsk, traverses the central portion of the island as far north as Addaima, and the other runs from the Seltonai mines, following the coast of the Golf of Tartary, through Alexandrovsk, to Pogobi, where the strait between Saghalien and the mainland of Asia is only some eight miles wide. The ferry at this gap famishes the means of communica- tion with the continent, and here also is the submarine telegraph. In the first case the road is nearly as long as that from London to Edin- burgh ; in the second, the places named are about half that distance apart. Alexandrovsk is connected by a short line of railway with Uedelnikovsk, about half way to Rikovskoe, which is a place on the hills some sixty miles from the seaport of Alexandrovsk. The railroad was probably designed to connect the port with Rikovskoe, which is of some importance. Under Russian administration the island seems to have been divided into three districts, the bisecting line running north and south through the mountainous region in the centre to about the fiftieth parallel of latitude, the whole of the land south of that parallel forming the third division. The southern portion was nam- ed the Korsakovsk district, that to the north- east the Chimovsk region, and that to the north-west the Alexandrovsk division. Mouka, of which the Japanese had obtained possession last Friday, is twenty miles to the north of the port of Alexandrovsk, and there was nothing left to capture save the town of that name itself, which is the most important on the island. It has a lighthouse at the entrance of its harbour, the only other light being that on Cape Notoro in La Perouse Strait, at the extreme southern point of Saghalien. One is badly needed at Telpenia Cape, which forms the eastern pro- montory of the East or Telpenia Bay to the northward of Aniwa Bay, in which stands Korsakovsk. North of Pogobi the island is uninhabited, and covered with dense forest for a hundred and fifty miles. The principal fight- ing was done at Davlin, which is about fifty miles south-east of the port of Alexandrovsk. A large river flows from the northward into Telpenia Bay, and the available road is parallel to the course of this stream for a little over one hundred miles, until Davlin is reached.
The Amur Expedition.

The River Amur debouches into the Hei- Lung-Wan, or Bay of the Black Dragon, togive it the correct Chinese title, bat it is named Amur Gulf on foreign charts. Immediately north of Hei-Lung-Wan is Savarin Bay, where Japanese warships are reported to be gather- ing, and the inference is that an expedition is in contemplation the details of which it would not be prudent at present to disclose. From the mouth of the Amur to Khabarovka the distance up stream is roughly 450 miles, and it is close upon 500 miles more up the Sun- gari to Kharbin. Vessels of large size can get up to Khabarovka and those of smaller ton- nage can ascend the tributary the whole way to Kharbio, and even beyond. There is nothing impracticable, it may be urged, in armed vessels and transports making their way up river to Khabarovka, and barges and lighters might be towed by specially suitable tugboats or other steamers the remainder of the dis- tance, and though it would be slow work against the current the chances are that the entire journey by water could be accomplish- ed in a fortnight. It is not impossible, therefore, that when the conference meets in Washington there may be a somewhat altered situation to discuss and to serve as the basis of consideration, if the preliminaries to negotia- tion should by that time have been fully ar- ranged. So far there is a lingering suspicion in men’s minds that though the Japanese pleni- potentiaries are undoubtedly armed with the powers which the term signifies, it may be found at the last moment that Russia has not been equally careful to avoid the inevitable de- lay which would ensue should it turn out that her representative is a plenipotentiary only in name. If the riverine expedition to Kharbin which, it is suggested, may be in contompla- tion should actually have been determined upon, the present is undoubtedly the most favorable, and almost the only season for its accomplishment. The Ussuri is navigable to a point near Lake Hinka, as well as the Sungari to Kharbin, for vessels of light draught, and the waterways are certain to be utilised this summer to very great advantage by the Japanese Army, even if it should not be deem- ed expedient to attempt the colossal under taking here foreshadowed. In Japan there has been a fairly general comprehension of the plan of campaign, though little or nothing has appeared in the public press which would be likely to convey an inkling of it to the other side. The map of Saghalien, moreover, was not issued until the expedition was about to start, and it then gave to the readers of the war news throughout the country an idea of the natural difficulties with which the troops were likely to meet in traversing the island.

div.head: BLOCKADE OF LONDON.
BY A BLOCKADE RUNNER
div.p: “Where do you think you’re going to ? the policeman inquired. “’Eaven knows,” said the cabman, piously, “Bout a ’our ago I ’oped I was goin’ to Charin’-cross. But I see as that won’t be in this life.” “Ah !” says the police- man, “you’d better be thinking about the next life, you had.” The cabman answered, and his answer was humorous but wholly unfit for publication. There was plenty of leisure for repartee. The cab, the cabman, and I, toge- ther with many other cabs, many other cab- men, and some solid columns of ’buses, were waiting for each other to pass at the point where Tottenham court road and Charing-cross- road meet Oxford-street. It is an interesting spot for those people whom police-cunrt reports describe as "gentlemen.” Anyone who gets his living without working for it will find that corner a most amusing lounge. One of the two great streams of London’s East and West traffic flows—or rather tries to flow—by ; another great stream between North and South , cuts across it at right-angles ; and there are half a dozen subsidiary streams which do not wish to flow straight, but to turn in among the others from West, or similar disturbing directions.

There are few busier crossings in London. That no doubt is why it was seized upon by the miscreants who blockade London for a permanent fortification. Redoubts and earth- works have been at the top of Charing-cross- road so long that, as the lawyers say, the “memory of man runneth not to the contrary.” Aged men relate with quavering voices that the original pretext for excavation was the making of underground lavatories. It may be so. At least, coyly sheltering under the shadow of the present fortifications, you find such places existing. But they are finished, and the excavation is not. No serious man supposes that it ever will be. The present pretext is understood to be the construction of a tube railway. When that is finished of course the road will want repaving, and then it will be time for the gas and water and electric light companion to have a turn—not simultaneously, but one after the other. But they will not be wanted just yet. The present fortifications are very strong. There are two large excavations some yards apart, each with a crane of its own. Small protecting trenches have been dug irregularly. To prevent the traffic approaching too close to the outer wall of the main excava- tion the asphalt of half the roadway has been picked up. This last device could only have sprung from an acute mind, for it causes the maximum amount of public inconvenience at the smallest cost in labour. The result put briefly is profanity. Policemen, good, well- meaning policemen, wander helplessly in and out of the traffic asking the drivers of vehicles where they want to go to, and making things as pleasant as possible. But it is not possible to be very pleasant when you know your train is puffing gaily out of Charing-cross, and you are at the wrong end of Charing cross-road.

My horse woke up and my cab slid across at last and we broke into a sprint. Cabby meant to show what be and the “old ’oss” could do, and I, who knew that whatever they did would make no difference to me, began to become philosophical. I must own that I expected a clear run to Shaftesbury- avenue. But “'tis all a cheat” ; 200 yards on there is a trench dug half-way or more across the road. Two drays and a baker’s hand-cart block the clear space. The “old ’oss” slides along on his haunches and cabby swears, and I daresay the horse does too, and we all survey the trench. It is very neatly dug and railed in, but quite, quite forlorn. Nobody is attending to it Nobody but the “old ’oss” is anywhere near it. It has just grown there. “Gentle shepherd, tell me why ?” You would suppose that a trench would not be dug without some object; that, having been dug, it would be used. Not so. It is left to mature. I begin to believe that there is a society of miscreants who go out and make excavations and earthworks simply to blockade London. They dig a trench and rail it in and go out of town. Six months afterwards the local borough council hears of it and accuses the Water Board and the gas company and the electric light company, and they wrangle over it for six months more. Then some weak official, much badger- ed, begins to think that it most be a hole he made and forgot. So he sends out two men and a barrow and they take two years filling it in.

By the time I had elaborated that explana- tion we were moving again. Of other trenches beginning to protrude from side streets I caught glimpses. But they hindered us not. In one wild rash we came as far as the National Portrait Gallery. There a thick, yellow, un- savoury smoke loaded the air, though which I saw some men at dinger. They were repaving half the roadway. I do not complain of their being at dinner. Any man who could eat in that smoke deserves honor. Cabby and the horse and I were snorting and sneezing and quite still. Half the road was “up.” In the other half several flying columns, each with a base of supplies, were making reconnaissances into the drains. Between the drains and the tar-boilers a thin stream of traffic came slowly. Very, very slowly. There was an inspector of policemen wandering about, fingering his white gloves and looking homesick. He might as well have been at home. You cannot empty a reservoir through the neck of a pint-bottle with any speed, even if you are an inspector of police in white gloves.

Some time afterwards a porter woke me up and said that we were at Charing-cross. The shock was severe. Cabby looked at me, sorrow- fully, as I paid him. It was like parting from an old friend. On the platform I found one who should have been with me in the train that

was far away. “You missed it, too ?” I inquir- ed, with some satisfaction. He glared, "Wa- terloo-place is up,” said he. “And so is——.” And then I said hastily we would have lunch. "I’ve got here,” said he, "and I’m not going to try to get anywhere else to-day.” It seemed unlikely that we should get anywhere if we did try. We launched at the station. And we agreed that the Commission on London Traffic had omitted the only satisfactory means of locomotion from their report. Walking is the healthiest, safest, and by far the speediest method.

div.head: GENERAL SIR MONTAGU GERARD.
div.p: A Reuter telegram from St. Petersburg, dated July 27, says “General Sir Montagu Gerard, of the Indian Army, who has been attached to the Russian forces in Manchuria, has died of pneumonia at Irkutsk on his way home from Kharbin. He had been suffer- ing from an affection of the kidneys and pleuro-pneumonia, and had been only a few days at Irkutsk, whither he had been conveyed by hospital train.”

Sir Montagu Gerard was the second son of the late Mr. Archibald Gerard, of Rock- soles, Lanarkshire, by his marriage with Euphemia Erskine, eldest daughter and co heir of Sir John Robison, K.H. He was born in 1842 and educated at Stonyhurst, on the Continent, and at the Woolwich Academy. His elder brother is Father Gerard, S.J., of the Farm-street community, while two of his sisters (one of whom, Mme. de Laszowski, died recently) became well-known authors. Sir Montagu married, in 1888, Helen, young- est daughter of the late Sir Edward Meade, of Hill-street, Berkeley-square, by whom he leaves a son. He was the author of “Leaves from the diary of a soldier and sportsman,” published in 1903.

On April 19, 1864, he was gazetted to the Royal Artillery as a lieutenant. His first war service was in the Abyssinian expedition, 1867-68, for which he was mentioned in despatches and received the medal. In 1870 he joined the Bengal Staff corps as lieutenant, becoming captain in 1876. He served as brigade-major in the Afghan campaign of 1878 80, and had his horse wounded while escorting a convoy from Chura, action of Deh Sarak. He served with the 2nd Bazar Valley expedition, and in the defence of Jagdallak Pass, and accompanied the column to Sherpur in December, 1879, was present at the affair at Saidabad, the march from Kabul to the relief of Kandahar, and the battle of September 1. He was twice mentioned in despatches, and received the medal with two clasps, the bronze star, and the brevets of major and lieutenant-colonel. Serving next with the expedition of 1882, be was present at the landing after the bombardment of Alexandria, and at all the affairs in front of that town. He was D.A.A. and Q.M.G. Cavalry Divi- sion, and was present at the reconnaissance of August 5, the action of Kassassin, the battle of Tell-el-Kebir, and the surrender of Cairo, for which he was mentioned in despatches, and received the medal with clasp, the bronze star, the third class of the Medjidie, and was made a C.B. In 1885 he became colonel in the Army, and from April, 1888, to April, 1889, was district staff officer of the first class, Bengal. A year later he became lieutenant colonel, Indian Staff Corps. He became substantive colonel in 1802, in which year he was appoin- ted Military Attache at St Petersburg. He was Commissioner on the Pamir Demarcation Com- mission in 1895, and was brigadier-general in India from 1896 to 1899. He became major- general in 1897, lieutenant-general in 1900, and general in 1904. In addition to his other services he was engaged in secret service in Persia in 1885, and was in charge of the pre- sent Tsar’s tour of 1890 91. He was created K.C.S.I. in 1897 and K.C.B. in 1902.

div.head: A WELL-KNOWN ALPINE CLIMBER.
div.p: Francois Joseph Devouassoud, who died, at the age of 78, at his home near Chamonix, after a short illness, on July 20, was among the best known of the guides who accompanied the earlier Alpine climbers and explorers in their conquests and discoveries. A born ice- man and pathfinder, he had few equals on a difficult glacier, and his courage in meeting danger was equalled by his skill in avoiding it. In the early sixties he wandered widely in the Central and Eastern Alps with Mr. V. F. Tuckett aDd Mr. Douglas Freshfield. In later years, with them or other climbers (the Rev. H. B. George, Messrs. W. and Arthur Sidgwick, Mr. J. H. Wainewright), he visited almost every Alpine district and climb- ed innumerable new peaks and passes. As a traveller he was pre-eminent among Alpine guides. In 1868, and again in 1887, he was in the Caucasus ; he took part in the first ascents of Kastek, Elbruz, and Tetnuld ; he had climbed in the Pyrenees, the Abruzzi, Corsica, and the Algerian Atlas; he had visited Spain, Egypt, Syria, and Armenia. In early life be had been a schoolmaster, and his natural intelligence, many experiences, and varied reading, combined with a singularly modest, charming, and loyal character, made him as much valued as a companion as he was trusted as a guide. He remained the intimate friend of all his old employers, and his memory will be long cherished in the Alpine Club and in many English households. A few yews ago he was presented with a medal by the French Alpine club for his services as an explorer.

div.head: AVIS
div.p: La Municipalité met en adjudication les travaux de prolongement de la rue des Parcs au sud de l'ancien cimetière israélite jusqu’au fort el Nahas.
Le cautionnement est fixé à LE. 15.
Le cahier des charges est déposé an Bureau de la Voirie où il peut-être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 18 courant.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation la même jour à 5h.p.m.
L’enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: “Soumission pour les travaux de prolongement de la rue des Parcs.”

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d’une banque, d’après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 18 courant à midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée.
L'Administrateur.
(signé) W.P. Chataway.
Alexandrie, le 7 juillet 1905.

div.head: Egyptian Delta Light Railways Co., Limited.
div.p: Connections made with the most important trains of the State Railway in the Provinces of Behera, Gharbieh, Dakahlieh Charkieh and Galioubieh.Through service for goods between all stations of the Company andover 100 principal stations of the State Railway in Upper and Lower Egypt. Goods may also be through-booked from or to any station on Helouan Railway. The Company has 70 stations opened for public Telegraph Service in conjunction with all offices of the Government Telegraph Department.For time tables, tariffs and information apply to the offices at Cairo, Alexandria Damanhour, Tantah or Zagazig. 21416 31-12.905
